1.question: What is the primary reason cited for the 'enormous data growth' in commercial and scientific databases?

options.B: Global reduction in data collection costs
options.C: Advances in data generation and collection technologies
options.D: Increased computational power of modern computers

2.question: According to the document, where is large-scale data found?

options.A: Everywhere, in both commercial and scientific databases

3.question: Which of the following best describes the 'new mantra' regarding data collection?

options.A: Gather data sparingly to avoid storage issues.
options.B: Gather whatever data you can whenever and wherever possible.
options.C: Collect only data with clearly defined immediate value.
options.D: Focus only on structured data for efficient processing.

4.question: What is the expectation for gathered data, according to the document?

options.A: It will only be valuable for purposes not initially envisioned.
options.B: It will have value for its collected purpose or for a purpose not envisioned.
options.C: It will only be valuable for the purpose it was originally collected.
options.D: It will primarily serve as a historical archive.

5.question: According to the commercial viewpoint, why is data mining important? Select all that apply.

options.A: Competitive pressure demands better, customized services.
options.B: It eliminates the need for human analysts.
options.C: Computers have become cheaper and more powerful.
options.D: Lots of data is being collected and warehoused.

options.B: By replacing the need for scientific experiments.
options.C: By automating the analysis of massive datasets.
options.D: By reducing the overall volume of collected data.

options.A: Reducing poverty by increasing agriculture production.
options.B: Predicting the impact of climate change.
options.C: Eliminating the need for traditional education.
options.D: Improving health care and reducing costs.

options.D: Extracting useful patterns, insights, or knowledge

26.question: What is the difference between descriptive and predictive data mining?

options.A: Descriptive data mining focuses on future outcomes, while predictive focuses on past trends.
options.B: Descriptive data mining is quantitative, while predictive is qualitative.
options.C: Descriptive data mining uses statistical methods, while predictive uses machine learning.
options.D: Descriptive data mining describes existing data, while predictive data mining forecasts future outcomes.

options.B: Data cleaning, transformation, integration, and multidimensional data model

options.B: Grouping similar data points into clusters

options.C: To group similar data points together.
options.D: To generalize data into higher-level concepts.

37.question: Which of the following best describes cluster analysis?

options.A: A method to predict a continuous numerical value.
options.B: An unsupervised learning technique to group data into categories.
options.C: A process to identify frequently co-occurring items.
options.D: A supervised learning technique where class labels are known.

38.question: What is the fundamental principle of cluster analysis?

options.B: Maximizing intra-class similarity and minimizing inter-class similarity.
options.C: Maximizing inter-class similarity and minimizing intra-class similarity.
options.D: Minimizing both intra-class and inter-class similarity.

39.question: What is an 'outlier' in data mining?

options.A: A data cluster with high density.
options.B: A data object that does not comply with the general behavior of the data.
options.C: A data point that is part of the most frequent pattern.
options.D: A data object that perfectly aligns with the general data behavior.

40.question: For what real-world applications is outlier analysis particularly useful? Select all that apply.

options.A: Whether it is interesting or not.
options.D: The volume of data it encompasses.

options.A: The color scheme of the visualization
